Labour Market Momentum Signal

Labour market momentum: jobless claims and payroll growth dynamics.

As of Unknown

Gemini Summary

The analysis, solely based on the provided Labour Market Momentum data, indicates a **Neutral** regime in the US labor market as of November 30, 2025. The composite Labour Momentum score is currently 0.139 (calculated primarily from claims), following -0.113 in September 2025 (full composite). Initial Claims (ICSA) showed a year-on-year decline of 4.0% in November, signaling some strength. However, Continuing Claims (CCSA) rose 4.6% year-on-year for the same period, suggesting underlying weakness. Nonfarm Payrolls (PAYEMS) also exhibited softening momentum in September 2025, with a 3-month difference of only 187k, contributing to a negative Z-score (-0.495) for payrolls. Please note: The provided data is limited to the labor market. Analysis of equities, bonds, precious metals, and industrial metals is not possible with this dataset.

Technical Summary: The Labour Market Momentum signal consistently remains within the "Neutral" band (between -0.75 and 0.75). The signal's recent oscillation, from slightly negative (-0.113 in Sep-25) to slightly positive (0.139 in Nov-25), suggests an absence of clear directional conviction or sustained trend. This indicates a balanced, albeit somewhat mixed, technical outlook for the labor market, with no strong tightening or softening signals. The incomplete PAYEMS data for October and November limits a comprehensive, up-to-date technical inference for the full composite.

References:

  • Initial Claims, Seasonally Adjusted (ICSA) - Latest: 2025-11-30
  • Continuing Claims, Seasonally Adjusted (CCSA) - Latest: 2025-11-30
  • Total Nonfarm Payrolls, Seasonally Adjusted (PAYEMS) - Latest: 2025-09-30 (Particularly relevant for comprehensive labor market assessment)
Publicly available data that would significantly enhance future analysis includes broader macroeconomic indicators (e.g., GDP growth, inflation rates, interest rate expectations), equity market performance indices, bond yields, and commodity price trends, essential for a multi-asset class market view.
